We have only heard from #Pfizer so far. If this is true however, and an Emergency Use Authorization is granted, here is what it means. By the end of this year, people (outside of a clinical trial) could receive the #CovidVaccine for the first time. Potentially before Christmas.

Important Vaccine news. Just heard that #Pfizer CEO @albertbourla said "Our safety milestone has been achieved already, and we are preparing now for submissions" for FDA Emergency use Authorization. #CovidVaccine

More promising news today! This a.m. we learned that #Moderna's vaccine is 94% percent effective. From their early results of 30K people - 90 people in the placebo group developed Covid-19, 11 of them severely ill. In the vaccine group, only 5 became ill. (1/3) https://t.co/EBQKAkbQsV

You‚Äôve heard me use the term ‚Äúcompassion fade‚Äù a lot today. It‚Äôs this idea of when more people are affected by tragedy we actually begin to care less. It‚Äôs important to fight this feeling as this pandemic rages on. üéß to our episode about this here:
https://t.co/t6QhRNGQTO

On March 9th, I called this a pandemic. Today, I called this pandemic a humanitarian disaster. Those are not words I use lightly, but when there‚Äôs more than 60,000 people in the hospital and we could lose more than 2,000 lives a day by Jan, there‚Äôs no other way to describe this. https://t.co/KmWDFFnJhU

We also developed better tools to deal with this new disease - drugs like remdesivir, monoclonal antibody treatments, blood thinners, and steroids are now all used as treatments for patients infected with Covid-19. (10/12) 
https://t.co/2g9K7AO4Zx

With Covid-19 the lungs fill up with mucus. Too much oxygen pushed into the lungs can damage already delicate lung tissue - causing leaks, swelling & other damage. Instead, doctors positioned patients on their stomachs or sides - known as proning. (9/12)
https://t.co/TU8ocp7Hq5

But it is also because we are now better at treating Covid-19. In the spring, one doctor described his only tools as a ventilator and a patient's own immune system. But as we learned more about this disease, it turned out that ventilators weren‚Äôt always the answer (8/12)

Keep in mind, this measure isn‚Äôt perfect. It‚Äôs the # of deaths divided by the # of confirmed cases. At the beginning of the pandemic, the # of confirmed cases was lower because we weren‚Äôt testing as much. So death rates in the spring may have been artificially high. (5/12)

One study of the @nyulangone health system found that in the spring, 25.6% of hospitalized Covid-19 patients wound up dying. By the summer, that rate had dropped by more than 2/3rds to 7.6%. (3/12)
https://t.co/qyruByJNB2

But there is some glimmer of hope - a smaller percentage of people are dying now from Covid-19 than in the spring. (2/12) 
https://t.co/74Xa0N8ZjC

We‚Äôve reached another sad milestone in this pandemic. 
The US has surpassed a record of more than 60k Covid-19 hospitalizations for the 2nd consecutive day. (1/12) https://t.co/TyQ6b0xpqG

This is good news - but there are still more questions. Consider this: we already know over 80% of people recover from #COVID19 with mild or no symptoms. A reasonable question: what is the vaccine‚Äôs effectiveness at preventing serious disease? I asked @AlbertBourla myself. (4/10) https://t.co/ZpFwXt2LMe

I want to take a moment to explain the big vaccine news today. #Pfizer is reporting early data showing their vaccine is ‚Äúmore than 90%‚Äù effective in preventing COVID-19. I spoke with #Pfizer‚Äôs CEO @AlbertBourla today, as the news broke early this morning (1/10) https://t.co/9eZy5rxRds

Just finished speaking to @pfizer CEO @AlbertBourla about #COVID19 #vaccine. Very promising to hear 90% effective, but questions remain, such as: how well the vaccine will protect against serious disease vs infection, overall safety data and how long immunity lasts.

I want to offer my congratulations to President-elect @JoeBiden, but also remind him that a record 126,480 Americans were diagnosed with Covid-19 yesterday. Cases are rising in 41 states & we're headed into a long winter. There are solutions, but they need to be implemented stat.
RT @abbear111: Today marks the first day of England‚Äôs second national lockdown, days after the U.K. surpassed 1 million coronavirus cases.‚Ä¶

I know there‚Äôs a lot of focus on the election, but we cannot forget the virus. Yesterday we had more than 121,000 new Covid-19 cases ‚Äì a record high. This is a stark reminder that though we have been at this for eight months, the pandemic is not over. Be kind and wear a mask.
